resource/csdk/connectivity/lib/libcoap-4.message:
According to this post in the Iotivity-Dev mailing list (http://lists.iotivity.org/pipermail/iotivity-dev/2015-February/000227.html) we need to add, support, and implement within our own stack 2.03, 2.04, and 2.05 as per the CoAP spec. Supposedly the CoAP spec has stated we should have been supporting these transport codes as early as 2011 (thats before we even started this project!).

I suggest we add support for them here (ie, simply add the few lines here for 2.04 & 2.05 and comment appropriately from the spec (https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-core-coap-18#section-5.9).

Jira ticket: https://jira.iotivity.org/browse/IOT-319

resource/csdk/connectivity/src/caretrans.message:
This change looks a good step forward. But, I am still bothered by two things:

1. We have (x * (uint64_t) MSECS_PER_SEC) in several places, and x looks like a 32 bit number. Maybe you guys remember what kind of conversions is the compiler supposed to apply for that kind of mismatch, but for me it would be easier to understand that code if we changed it to:

((uint64_t)x * (uint64_t)MSECS_PER_SEC) 

2. We have now (uint64_t)MSECS_PER_SEC, but MSECS_PER_SEC is already defined as an uint64_t, so there is no need for this cast anymore.

Any thoughts about my two points above?
Please output a more verbose error message. Also use ERROR level when printing out an error message.

extlibs/tinydtls/debug.h.message:
I think the root-cause for this issue is the way autotools are generating the Makefiles.

'debug.c' contains the definition of 'dtls_package_version' method.

When configured with '--without-debug', Makefile for libtinydtls.a does NOT 
include 'debug.c' in SOURCES to be compiled. 
whereas, when configured without '--without-debug', Makefile for libtinydtls.a does includes 'debug.c' in SOURCES to be compiled.

I would rather suggest to make 'dtls_package_version' and 'dtls_package_name' as inline methods and include them in debug.h with the '#ifndef NDEBUG' condition. Also, remove the definition from debug.c file.

resource/csdk/security/src/iotvticalenda.message: This will work for period 20151015T080000/20151015T220000 but will fail for period 20151013T080000/20151016T220000 provided current date 20151015 and time is 7am. We only want to check start time if current date is 20151013(start date) and end time if current date is 20151016(end date) as valid period starts from 20151013T080000 and ends at 20151016T220000. If we check start and end time for day in between start and end date we will get unexpected results.

resource/c_common/oic_string/src/oic_str.message:
To clarify, it appears that this change in and of itself would not directly address the described problem. However it instead looks to be a work-around for problems that lie elsewhere.

Null pointer strings and empty (valid pointer to a single null-termination character) should both be handled. Also either can be passed safely to free(), so that does seem to indicate problems elsewhere in the code.

The main concern with changes such as this would be that the change in behavior that compensates for one area of code might introduce problems elsewhere.

resource/include/AttributeValue.h.message:
The whole idea of the int->int64_t change was to make sure that we don't run into issues when someone first saves a value using an "int" type and elsewhere try to retrieve an int64_t type.

There was a lengthy discussion about this problem in the IoTivity-dev thread " Integer representation in OCRepresentation, OCRepPayload and cbor encoder" where we agreed to use int64_t only and verify if the value is in the correct range, when someone tries to retrieve an "int" value.

Hint: it's a good practice to *not* include the "count of" enumerations in the enum in the enum itself. Instead, put it in a separate enum:

 enum { NUM_OC_STATUS_CODES = OC_STATUS_PROXYING_NOT_SUPPORTED + 1 };

That way, you can use the exhaustive-switch solution and then the compiler warns if you forgot any entry.

But you won't need the count if we drop the need for the array itself, if you use a 1:1 mapping.

This is markdown then I would encourage to use markdown for the links

Links
Markdown supports two style of links: inline and reference.
In both styles, the link text is delimited by [square brackets].
To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately after the link text’s closing square bracket. Inside the parentheses, put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an optional title for the link, surrounded in quotes. For example:
This is [an example](http://example.com/ "Title") inline link.

[This link](http://example.net/) has no title attribute.

if you want to use reference style links then you can use this page to see the syntax.

https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#link

If you just want plain text without links let me know.

resource/csdk/security/unittest/base64te.message:
Take a look at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3378560/how-to-disable-gcc-warnings-for-a-few-lines-of-code

I like the idea that Martin Gerhardy was doing but don't really like the macros he came up with. We could add macros like.

OC_GCC_DISABLE_WARNING("-Wdepricated-declarations")
OC_GCC_ENABLE_WARNING("-Wdepricated-declarations")

that are expanded to the #pragma including the #ifdef(__GNUC__) .. #endif

This could be expanded for Microsoft something like

OC_MSC_DISABLE_WARNING(msvc_errorcode)
OC_MSC_ENABLE_WARNING(msvc_errorcode)

I like this over the one in the stackoverflow because you don't have to know the warning for all the compilers to use the macro you can target a specific compiler. 

If we added macros I would add them to the documentation for OC_DEPRICATED

This is me also thinking out loud. :)

I understand your idea.
But I have one concern about that. this change is because when send function is failed, tls peer need to be free (especially handshake step). That means when send fail, mbedtls_ssl_read return minus value. As you can see in oc_tls line 951~975 return 0 is not going to free peer buffer. Then when application retry some message send, this will stuck in handshake step.
Is it okay to let this happen remain?

If this is fine, I will change to return value to 0 when error occur.
